abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: In this we collect and document all specialties.

sec.title: Theorem/Lemma/etc Environments
sec.p: Theorems should have a clearly visible scope (beginning and end). Typically, this is achieved by making the entire body of the theorem italic. Lemmas, Propositions, Corollaries, named theorems, etc., should be typeset similarly to theorems. These environments have disp-level thmplain.
Typically, the body of a definition begins on the same line as the title. The title is typeset in bold or smallcaps.

sec.title: Theorem 1.1 ([2, Theorem 1])
sec.p: If m \geq |\ell | - \ell , then all the zeros of f_{k,m}(z) in \mathcal {F} lie on \mathcal {A}.
Theorems can contain multiple paragraphs, display formulas and other block-level content such as lists.

sec.title: Corollary 1.2 (Height estimate for cmc surfaces)
sec.p: Let \Sigma be a compact surface having constant mean curvature which is embedded in {\mathbb M}^2(c) \times {\mathbb R} and a graph over {\mathbb M}^2(c) \times \{0\} such that \partial \Sigma \subset {\mathbb M}^2(c) \times \{0\}. Suppose that
then
Theorems can have custom titles.

sec.title: Main Theorem
sec.p: where k_\mathbf {m}=m_1+m_2+m_3-1+\operatorname {ord}_\mathbf {m}(f_2)-\operatorname {ord}_\mathbf {m}(f_1).
Theorems should also look good when their body ends with a display formula.

sec.title: Theorem 2.1 (Howald's Theorem [4])
sec.p: Let I\subseteq \mathbb {C}[x_1,\mathinner {\ldotp \ldotp \ldotp },x_r], let P(I)\subseteq \mathbb {R}^r be the Newton polyhedron of I, let \operatorname {int}(\lambda \cdot P(I)) be the interior of the dilated polyhedron, and let \mathbf {1}=(1,\mathinner {\ldotp \ldotp \ldotp },1)\in \mathbb {N}^r. Then, the multiplier ideal \mathcal {J}(I^\lambda ) is the monomial ideal
Lemmas have the same style as theorems.

sec.title: Lemma 3.2
sec.p: I\cdot \mathcal {O}_{X_{\Sigma _1}} has an embedded component exactly when \operatorname {ord}_\mathbf {n}(f_1)\!<\!\operatorname {ord}_\mathbf {n}(f_2) and f_1 cuts out the embedded curve on the exceptional divisor set-theoretically in this case.

sec.title: Definition Environments
sec.p: Definitions can have a more lightweight design than theorems. It is less important that the scope is clearly shown, e.g., definitions are rendered without italics. Definitions have disp-level thmdefinition. Note that Examples also have disp-level thmdefinition.
Typically, the body of a definition begins on the same line as the title. The title is typeset as titles of theorems, in bold or in smallcaps.

sec.title: Definition 1.1
sec.p: Let X be a smooth irreducible variety over \mathbb {C}. Let I\subseteq \mathcal {O}_X be a nonzero ideal sheaf and let \lambda >0 be a rational number. Fix a log resolution \mu :\widetilde {X}\to X of I and let F be the effective divisor such that I\cdot \mathcal {O}_X=\mathcal {O}_{\widetilde {X}}(-F). The multiplier ideal \mathcal {J}(I^{\lambda })\subseteq \mathcal {O}_X associated to \lambda and I is defined to be

sec.title: Remark, etc Environments
sec.p: Remarks, etc can have an even more lightweight visual design than definitions. They have disp-level thmremark
Typically, the body of a definition begins on the same line as the title. The title is typeset as titles of theorems, in bold or in smallcaps.

sec.title: Remark 2.6
sec.p: If either r=0 or r=1, we get respectively for m=2 the following formulae:

sec.title: Design for Proof environments (#5)
sec.p: Proof environments have clear scope (beginning and end). The beginning is marked with the title (usually the word "Proof.") and the end is marked with the QED symbol (usually an empty square that is flush-right). The body text begins on the same line as the title and ends on the same line as the QED symbol.

sec.title: Proof.
sec.p: The proof uses the same argument as the proof of Lemma 4.2 in [4], with the only difference being that in our case S_r is not assumed to be constant on \Sigma .

sec.title: Proof.
sec.p: Now we study embedded components on X_{\Sigma _1} in order to understand how to build our good toric variety X. Let S be the coordinate ring of X_{\rho }. Then

and IS=(y^{\operatorname {ord}_\mathbf {n}(f_1)}g_1,y^{\operatorname {ord}_\mathbf {n}(f_2)}g_2,\mathinner {\ldotp \ldotp \ldotp }) where (g_1,g_2,\mathinner {\ldotp \ldotp \ldotp }) is the ideal of the strict transform and (y) is the prime ideal corresponding to the exceptional divisor. We know that the strict transform is smooth and meets the exceptional divisor transversally. In particular, IS is generated by two elements. When we combine this with the fact that we wrote the generators in order of increasing order of vanishing, we have

From this calculation, we see that I\cdot \mathcal {O}_{X_{\Sigma _1}} has an embedded component exactly when \operatorname {ord}_\mathbf {n}(f_1)<\operatorname {ord}_\mathbf {n}(f_2) and f_1 cuts out the embedded curve on the exceptional divisor set-theoretically in this case.
Proofs can contain nested block-level environments (such as Lemmas and Proofs), though that is rare.

sec.title: Proof.
sec.p: Let us suppose by absurdity that S is a properly embedded SWET surface with finite topology and one end with respect to a function f which also satisfies the hypotheses of Theorems 1.1, 1.3.

Let us denote by D a constant bigger than \max \{C,d \}, where C is the bound for the horizontal height given by Theorem 1.3 and d is the horizontal diameter of the sphere of constant mean curvature equal to H_0.

Let p denote a point in S and \gamma a horizontal geodesic containing p. Let p_1,p_2 be two points in \gamma such that dist_{{\mathbb H}^2(c)}(p,p_1)=dist_{{\mathbb H}^2(c)}(p_1,p_2)=D, dist_{{\mathbb H}^2(c)}(p,p_2)=2D. Let P_1,P_2 be two vertical totally geodesic planes intersecting orthogonally with \gamma at p_1,p_2 respectively.
We now use the following variant of the Plane Separation Lemma proved in [13]. Its proof is exactly the same.

sec.label: Lemma 2.14
sec.p: Let S be a properly embedded SWET annulus in {\mathbb H}^2(c) \times {\mathbb R}. Suppose that f \geq H_0 > \frac {\sqrt {-c}}2. Let P_1 and P_2 be two vertical totally geodesic planes. Assume that the distance between P_1 and P_2 is bigger than the horizontal diameter of the sphere of constant mean curvature H_0. Denote by P_1^+ and P_2^+ the components of {\mathbb H}^2(c) \times {\mathbb R}\setminus P_j such that P_1^+ \cap P_2^+ =\emptyset . Then all the connected components of S \cap P_1^+ or S \cap P_2^+ are compact.

The distance between P_1 and P_2 equals D>d; then the previous lemma applies. Suppose that all of the connected components of S \cap P_1^+ are compact. By construction the plane P_1 is at distance D to the point p \in S \cap P_1^+. As D>C, C being the bound for the horizontal distance, this would contradict Theorem 1.3. Then all the connected components of S \cap P_2^+ are compact. By Theorem 1.3 the points of S \cap P_2^+ are at a distance to P_2 which has to be smaller than C.

If we use the same argument after replacing \gamma by every other horizontal geodesic line passing by p, we can prove that S is located at finite distance to \{p\} \times {\mathbb R}. In other words, S is contained in a vertical cylinder.
As by hypothesis S has exactly one end, we can assume that S is contained in the halfspace \{t \leq 0\} and is tangent to \{t=0 \}.

For z<0 we consider the reflection in \{t=z \} of the compact piece S_z of S contained in \{z \leq t \leq 0\}. We will show that S_z is a vertical graph on \{t=z \} for any z<0. We denote by S_z^R the reflection of S_z in \{t=z \}. We observe that S_z^R does not have common tangent points with S. Otherwise by the Maximum Principle, Proposition 2.11, we could conclude that S is compact. For the same reason S_z^R and S_z are not orthogonal to \{t=z \} for any z<0. This proves that S_z is a graph.
Now we can choose z_0<0 with |z_0| big enough so that the height of the compact graph S_{z_0} (having boundary on the plane \{t =z_0\}) is arbitrarily big. This contradicts Theorem 1.1.

sec.title: Display Formulas have too much padding (#6)
sec.p: As display formulas are frequent and can contain very big as well as very small expressions, spacing around display formulas should be kept to a minimum.

sec.title: Isolated display formulas
sec.p: The multiplier ideal does not depend upon the choice of log resolution. If, in addition, we assume X=\operatorname {Spec}R is affine, we also have the following formula, essentially due to Lipman [7]:

In this work we will consider special Weingarten surfaces of elliptic type in {\mathbb M}^2(c) \times {\mathbb R}. Here {\mathbb M}^2(c)={\mathbb S}^2(c),{\mathbb R}^2 or {\mathbb H}^2(c) depending on the sign of the sectional curvature c. If H and K_e denote the mean curvature and the extrinsic Gauss curvature of a surface \Sigma respectively, then \Sigma is called a special Weingarten surface if the following identity holds:

with f\in {\mathcal C}^0([0,+\infty )). Furthermore if f\in {\mathcal C}^1([0,+\infty )) and 4x(f'(x))^2<1 \, \forall x\in [0,+\infty ), then f is said to be elliptic and \Sigma is said to be a special Weingarten surface of elliptic type, henceforth called a SWET surface.

sec.title: Text bodies with frequent use of display formulas

If we set \Omega _1=\bigcup _k Q_{ 1,k}, then

and where f_Q=\frac {1}{|Q|}\intop \nolimits _Q f. The “good” function g_1 satisfies, for any s\geq 1,
and b_1 is written as

We do the same for f_2. Via the Calderón-Zygmund decomposition at the same level \lambda , we obtain a collection of of dyadic non-overlapping cubes Q_{ 2,k} with union \Omega _2 and analogous decomposition f_2=g_2+b_2 with the properties described for f_1. Set

sec.title: Equation Arrays
sec.p: We split the distribution set we are trying to estimate into several parts as follows:

sec.title: Highlighting of Environments when "active" (#7)
sec.p: Clicking a reference to a block-level environment such as a theorem or defition, should display the referenced environment in the right-hand side pane. Also, the target environment should be highlighted in the body and in the "outline" scroll-bar.
Conversely, selecting a block-level envrionment should highlight the places in the text where it is referenced.

sec.title: Theorem 2.4
sec.p: Let I\subseteq \mathbb {C}[x_1,\mathinner {\ldotp \ldotp \ldotp },x_r] be a prime of height c, let Z=Z(I)\subseteq X be the subvariety cut out by I, let \mu :\widetilde {X}\to X be a strong factorizing desingularization of Z, let \widetilde {Z} be the strict transform of Z, let \mathcal {L} be the invertible sheaf such that I\cdot \mathcal {O}_{\widetilde {X}}=\mathcal {L}\cdot \mathcal {I}_{\widetilde {Z}} and let \mathfrak {b}=\mu _*\mathcal {L}. Then
This paragraph references the preceeding theorem: Theorem 2.4.
This paragraph references environments further above: Lemma 3.2 and Definition 1.1.

sec.title: Support def-lists (#10)
sec.p: def-lists should be rendered properly. They are needed, because the Latex -> XML converter uses def-lists to represent enumerations (ordered lists) with custom counters.
The following should be a list with three four items labeled (1) through (4):

def.p: E is a divisor with simple normal crossings support.
At each step the blowup center is disjoint from the regular locus of the strict transform.
\widetilde {Z} is smooth and has simple normal crossings with E.
\cdot \mathcal {O}_{\widetilde {X}}=\mathcal {L}\cdot \_{\widetilde {Z}} where \mathcal {I}_{\widetilde {Z}} is the ideal sheaf of \widetilde {Z} and \mathcal {L}=\mathcal {O}_{\widetilde {X}}(-E).
